name: Abundance conjecture
summary:
The abundance conjecture in algebraic geometry is a birational geometry conjecture, specifically in the minimal model program, which states that if the canonical bundle {\displaystyle K_{X}} is nef, then {\displaystyle K_{X}} is semi-ample, meaning that {\displaystyle mK_{X}} is base-point free for some {\displaystyle m>0}. This is true for every projective variety {\displaystyle X} with Kawamata log terminal singularities over a field {\displaystyle k}. Specifically, if abundance is maintained, the model {\displaystyle X\rightarrow Y=\mathrm {Proj} \bigoplus _{l\geqslant 0}H^{0}(X,lK_{X})$ can be defined.

Caucher Birkar has established important cases of the abundance conjecture.[1]
